description: A clinical dataset containing medical records of 299 heart failure patients collected at the Faisalabad Institute of Cardiology and at the Allied Hospital in Faisalabad (Punjab, Pakistan) during April-December 2015. The dataset is used to predict mortality by heart failure and includes 13 clinical features that are commonly collected during follow-up visits.

original_source.creator: Davide Chicco and Giuseppe Jurman
original_source.institution: Faisalabad Institute of Cardiology and Allied Hospital, Faisalabad
original_source.publication: Chicco, D., Jurman, G. Machine learning can predict survival of patients with heart failure from serum creatinine and ejection fraction alone. BMC Medical Informatics and Decision Making 20, 16 (2020)

columns.name: age
columns.semantic_description: Age of the patient at the time of data collection

columns.name: anaemia
columns.semantic_description: Decrease of red blood cells or hemoglobin. Indicates if patient has anaemia

columns.name: creatinine_phosphokinase
columns.semantic_description: Level of CPK enzyme in blood, indicating damage to heart muscle

columns.name: ejection_fraction
columns.semantic_description: Percentage of blood leaving the heart at each contraction

columns.name: serum_creatinine
columns.semantic_description: Level of serum creatinine in blood, indicating kidney function

columns.name: serum_sodium
columns.semantic_description: Level of serum sodium in blood, indicating electrolyte balance

columns.name: death_event
columns.semantic_description: If the patient died during the follow-up period

target_description.name: platelets
target_description.meaning: Count of platelets in the blood, which are crucial for blood clotting and cardiovascular health

dataset_history: The dataset was collected during a study of heart failure patients in Pakistan during 2015. It represents a comprehensive clinical follow-up of patients with various cardiovascular conditions and comorbidities. The data was collected to study mortality prediction in heart failure patients and has become an important benchmark dataset for medical predictive modeling.
inference_notes: The dataset has some important considerations: 1) It represents a specific geographic population in Pakistan, which may affect generalizability, 2) The follow-up period varies among patients, 3) Some features like smoking status are self-reported and may have reporting bias, 4) The dataset is relatively small (299 instances) which may affect model robustness, 5) There's class imbalance in the death_event outcome which should be considered in classification tasks.
